definition: to copy something exactly
to produce exact copies of itself
connected with the way in which something is built or organized
people who are suicidal feel that they want to kill themselves
very dangerous and likely to lead to the person's own death; likely to cause them very serious problems or disaster
to make somebody sad
the quality of being easily made into different shapes
what you do, say or think as a result of something that has happened
a change in people’s attitudes or behaviour caused by disapproval of the attitudes, etc. of the past
a response by the body, usually a bad one, to a drug, chemical substance, etc.
the ability to move quickly in response to something, especially if in danger
a chemical change produced by two or more substances acting on each other
a force shown by something in response to another force, which is of equal strength and acts in the opposite direction
opposition to social or political progress or change
a description of how things might happen in the future
a written outline of what happens in a film or play
in the direction of somebody/something
getting closer to achieving something
close or closer to a point in time
in relation to somebody/something
with the aim of obtaining something, or helping somebody to obtain something
a gene which causes a section of DNA to copy itself
an idea that is passed from one member of society to another, not in the genes but often by people copying it
an image, a video, a piece of text, etc. that is passed very quickly from one internet user to another, often with slight changes that make it humorous
a feature or quality that is typical of somebody/something
a mark put on gold, silver and platinum objects that shows the quality of the metal and gives information about when and where the object was made
to use pictures, photographs, diagrams, etc. in a book, etc.
to make the meaning of something clearer by using examples, pictures, etc.
to show that something is true or that a situation exists
to carefully examine the facts of a situation, an event, a crime, etc. to find out the truth about it or how it happened
to try to find out information about somebody’s character, activities, etc.
to find out information and facts about a subject or problem by study or research
having a good chance of happening or being something; probable or expected
seeming suitable for a purpose
used to show that you do not believe what somebody has said
not supporting or helping either side in a disagreement, competition, etc.
not belonging to any of the countries that are involved in a war; not supporting any of the countries involved in a war
deliberately not expressing any strong feeling
not affected by something
not very bright or strong, such as grey or light brown
neither acid nor alkaline
having neither a positive nor a negative electrical charge
in a place that has no connection with either of the people or sides who are meeting and so does not give an advantage to either of them
having several dimensions (= measurements in space)
having many cells
done or shared by all members of a group of people; involving a whole group or society
used to refer to all members of a group
an affix or word that shows that a word belongs to a group of words with similar meanings. For example the prefix ‘un’ is a classifier that shows the word is negative.
a living thing, real or imaginary, that can move around, such as an animal
a person, considered in a particular way
a person or thing that depends completely on somebody else and is controlled by them
connected with hearing
new and still developing

(1905-93) a US dancer and choreographer . She created a new type of dance for Broadway musical shows when she combined ballet with popular music for Oklahoma! (1943) and later for Carousel (1945) and Paint Your Wagon (1951). Her ballets included Black Ritual (1940) and Fall River Legend (1948). In the early part of her career she danced in London with the dance company now known as Rambert. Her uncle was Cecil B De Mille. “The truest expression of a people is in its dances and its music. Bodies never lie.”Agnes de Mille
to write something again in a different way, usually in order to improve it or because there is some new information
in a complete, efficient or determined way that follows a system or plan
in a way that is not organized into a clear system
a change or set of changes to something
the act of changing something, or of examining something with the intention of changing it
the process of learning work for an exam
in the form of a statement
a person whose job is to plan the growth and development of a town
a person who makes plans for a particular area of activity
a book, chart, computer program, etc. that contains dates and is used for recording information, arranging meetings, etc.
to find a way of dealing with a problem or difficult situation
to find the correct answer or explanation for something
the various aspects of a person’s character that combine to make them different from other people
the qualities of a person’s character that make them interesting and attractive
a famous person, especially one who works in entertainment or sport
a person whose strong character attracts attention
the qualities of a place or thing that make it interesting and different
connected with the relationship between two things, where one causes the other to happen
a word such as because that introduces a statement about the cause of something
connected with a system, used especially in computing and electronics, that uses only the numbers 1 (to show something is true) and 0 (to show something is false)
a group of words that includes a subject and a verb, and forms a sentence or part of a sentence
an item in a legal document that says that a particular thing must or must not be done
in a way that is based on experiments or experience rather than ideas or theories
connected with art or computer graphics
in the form of a diagram or graph
connected with what something is like or how good it is, rather than with how much of it there is
the act of writing words or letters using letters of a different alphabet or language
the fact of being in a particular place
the fact of being in a particular place or thing
a group of people, especially soldiers, who have been sent to a place to deal with a particular situation
a person or spirit that you cannot see but that you feel is near
the quality of making a strong impression on other people by the way you talk or behave; a person who has this quality
with somebody in the same place
when something exists in a particular place
to do something to make people very aware of the fact that you are there; to have a strong influence on a group of people or a situation
a person who finds an answer to a problem or a difficult situation
the action of making somebody do something that they do not want to do, using force or threatening to use force
the state of being together in the same place at the same time
a box in which a dead body is buried or cremated
something that makes the end or failure of an organization, somebody’s plans, etc. more likely to happen
to rest while you are doing something that you enjoy, especially after work or effort
to become or make somebody become calmer and less worried
to become or make something become less tight or stiff
to allow rules, laws, etc. to become less strict
to allow your attention or effort to become weaker
a style or method in art, music, literature, etc. that pays more attention to the rules and the correct arrangement and appearance of things than to inner meaning and feelings
the general health, happiness and safety of a person, an animal or a group
practical or financial help that is provided, often by the government, for people or animals that need it
money that the government pays regularly to people who are poor, unemployed, sick, etc.
a thing that you are given because you have done something good, worked hard, etc.
an amount of money that is offered to somebody for helping the police to find a criminal or for finding something that is lost
the reward for acting in a moral or correct way is the knowledge that you have done so, and you should not expect more than this, for example praise from other people or payment
the process of going back to an earlier or less advanced form or state
the process of developing gradually from one stage or state to another
a number of things that come in a series
small and not important
relating to or resulting from small changes
not part of a main or important group or situation
won or lost by a very small number of votes and therefore very important or interesting as evidence of public opinion
written in the margin of a page
that cannot produce enough good crops to make a profit
a small group of people who spend their time together and do not allow others to join them
the use of a word that refers to or replaces another word used earlier in a sentence, for example the use of ‘does’ in the sentence ‘I disagree and so does John’
the act of repeating a word or phrase at the beginning of sentences or clauses that follow each other, done for emphasis
a person who has bipolar disorder
curving out
